Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: disagree and agree. Classify the comment as disagree if it expresses strong disagreement. Classify the comment as agree if no strong disagreement is expressed.

Comment: Mr. Gibson really should get some legal advice before he sticks his neck out and makes a fool of himself.

Section 92(10(a) empowers a province to legislate over various local works and undertakings:

            "(a) Lines of Steam or other Ships, Railways, Roads, Telegraphs, and other Works and Undertakings         connecting the Province with any other or others of the Provinces, or extending beyond the Limits of the Province

Pipelines are not mentioned.      

The federal Parliament  can, however, declare a work to be for the general benefit of Canada or three or more provinces under section 92(10(c):

           "(c) Such Works as, although wholly situate within the Province, are before or after their Execution declared by the Parliament of Canada to be for the general Advantage of Canada or for the Advantage of Three or more of the Provinces.

In the absence of a federal declaration, B.C. is within its rights to lay down condition for the expansion of this pipeline.

Comment: The declassified intel report, contained literally no evidence that Russia hacked anything.
Former CIA-agent Larry Johnson, about the report: “This thing, it’s a joke. If I’m a Russian intelligence analyst, with one of your intelligence services, I would be suspicious and think ‘What are the Americans up to? They really can’t be this stupid.’ And let me just reassure the folks on your side of the ledger – yeah, they actually are. ... They have no evidence. I've still got friends in the intelligence community. They're shaking their heads - they've got nothing."
Also, many prominent journalists mocked the report (many more than these):
Shaun Walker: "The NYT calls the report "damning and surprisingly detailed". We must be reading different reports"

Comment: There are few times when it is prudent to turn down economic development. 

Wages are so much higher in oil patch than in other sectors that other employers have trouble finding qualified employees.  The promising employees take the higher pay leaving a perpetual skills gap outside the oil patch.  Moreover, qualified people can and do leave for higher wages often at a lower skill level job in the oil patch.

In Alberta, the government spent 20 years promoting economic diversity only to find that the diverse businesses recruited could and would not compete with the oil and gas sectors on wages.  

Amazon is not looking for enough workers to cause such a problem (it will not reach 28% of the total provincial economy as the AB oil patch).  Ramp up educational programs that are relevant to Amazon's business.  You can cut the number of graduates in English Literature and increase the number in technical areas.

Objectors to Amazon resist raising their helps wages to Amazon levels.

Comment: There are two grievous flaws in the ignorant and idiotic statement "if you have nothing to hide, you have nothing to fear."

Firstly, it is not for YOU to decide what you do or do not have to hide --- that decision, rightly or wrongly (and it is mostly the latter) is in the hands of those in power, i.e. the government and their agents.  And more and more, they are deciding that you, we, DO have something to hide.

Secondly, effectively EVERYONE has something to hide, whether they realize it or not, due to the vast and ever-growing web of onerous and intrusive laws and regulations, particularly on the federal level.  It has been estimated that the average person breaks the law at least five times every day.  So anyone who dares to publicly speak out or resist those (unjust) laws will surely invite those in power to scrutinize their life and their past activities in order to find something with which to prosecute that person, particularly in this day of the death of privacy.

Comment: IF your gay brother was dying of AIDS, would you deny him the resources to save his life? If your sister attempted suicide, would your prefer that the paramedics let her bleed out? And if your overweight father- bless his soul- had a stroke or cardiac arrest, is it better that society just let him pass... given that he didn't look after himself and all?

This crisis raises no unique issues as far as society is concerned. First we try our best to save anyone in a life-threatening situation. If the same kind of life-threatening situation continues, we develop a longer-range strategy. The greatest danger to us all comes from those who would, in a panic, unwisely call for Draconian measures that would damage everyone. 

As with health crises in the past, we will successfully deal with this one. In the meantime, please don't write off your brother, sister, father or anyone else who suffers from the human condition.

Comment: I'm apparently not explaining clearly. Using a gun to wound is just as much using deadly force under the law as using it to kill. The intent in using deadly force, whether a gun or not, is to stop a threat. If the threat dies due to the application of deadly force so be it, that is a possible result, but not the intent. So, no, you aren't "trying to kill" you are trying to stop.

Since using a gun is using deadly force, no matter where you aim, to state you felt merely wounding was "sufficient" you are essentially admitting the threat you were facing didn't actually justify using the gun to stop it at all. You should have used some other proportional, non-lethal, method. To "shoot to wound" is the actual "over-kill," as in disproportionate use of force.

I recommend Andrew Branca's "Law of Self-Defense" for a better explanation of the subject.

  The only advice I can give people like me (older, widowed and alone) is take your time, and also to be careful of these local companies that offer to "help."   They will often overcharge and do a lousy job.  All they care about is getting as much of your money as they can get their hands on. DONATE instead.
 
  Get a hard quote/estimate/contract, pay as you go WEEKLY, not monthly. On every WEEKLY bill, don't be afraid to question any/every charge you don't understand.    

   Don't be afraid to fire them the minute you suspect they are overcharging, milking you for cash or taking advantage of you.  Some of these companies that "help people" are parasites.

Just speaking from experience.

Comment: A few things to note here:

First – weed today is not stronger than it was “back in the day”. That’s a myth and should have been caught by the editor before this garbage column was published. 

Second – the molecules that make up the smell of weed smoke are non-polar. This means they will only dissolve in oil and not water. That is why weed smoke – while you may not like the smell – is not very “sticky”. It goes away after awhile and doesn’t infest your clothes (unless you haven’t washed them in awhile in which case they will have a lot of body oil in them). The molecules that make tobacco smoke smell are polar molecules. This means they will dissolve in water. That is why being around someone who is smoking tobacco can make your clothes smell terrible later on and why tobacco smoke is so “sticky”. 

Third – weed doesn’t remove ambition. At least, it hasn’t removed mine. If anything it allows me to relax and decompress after a long week at work.

Worst. Eddie. Column. Ever.

Comment: Generally, drilling of gas and oil wells (most fields contain both) has slowed considerably since the Saudis engineered the glut. That situation will continue, in my opinion. One benefit is that tar sands extraction has been put on hold. I look forward to new technology to take the place of fossil fuel burning to make electricity, and technology to reduce energy requirements. The current petroleum glut is intended to reduce the world market price of oil to the benefit of Saudi Arabia. As a resource, petroleum is now adequate to supply demand. Low prices are the result of the glut, not the reverse. I agree that demand doesn't increase basic natural resources, but it stimulates their exploitation. We are in agreement on many of these issues. I only disagree, I think, on some of the details.

Comment: Cap and Trade is a disaster waiting to happen.  A fictitious market in fictitious pollution allowances, the profit from which goes directly into pork-barrelling otherwise economically unviable industries and projects.  Meanwhile carbon credit brokers get rich.

But as to Margaret's suggestion that, ". . . carbon taxes are simple, transparent and revenue-neutral . . ." that is patently untrue even when the government pretends it is so.  Think about it: government takes $20 from me as a carbon tax.  Government gives $20 to pet "environment friendly" project.  Government passes the $20 in and out and declares it neutral.  What nonsense - I'm out $20 and someone who didn't earn it now has my $20!  How is that neutral?

And it is only revenue neutral as long as the collector, government, decides to keep it so.  BC's new NDP government just this month quietly announced that carbon taxes would be dumped into provincial general revenue.  Not even a pretense of neutrality anymore.

Comment: That's how I remember it, too.  I don't believe I knew anyone who was openly gay until about 1970, or later, and I'm not even sure if that word (gay) had been adopted yet by homosexuals to identify themselves.  When I was a kid, the epithet we hurled was "queer" -- and it was meant to convey radical otherness, profound separation, deep contempt.  Who would willingly take that on?  No-one I knew.  My parents were old-school Irish Catholics, born early in the twentieth century.  They were not in any sense I can recall "liberal" or "progressive". But to their great credit, they taught us to respect persons and to never willingly, intentionally harm or hurt them.  And so for us, the "Q" word was as verboten as the "N" word. I'm grateful to my parents for teaching us this lesson of simple respect and decency.

Comment: This is a joke right?  Where are you guys getting your abridged version of history and law from anyway? The Settler Colonizer's Handbook? The White Supremacist's Guide to the Universe? The Supreme Court of Canada recognized Indigenous ownership and title to their traditional lands decades ago.  Recognition of Indigenous title is traced all the way back to the Royal Proclamation of 1763 where the King also recognized their title and agreed not to disturb it unless the land was ceded i.e. sold to the Crown.  Settlers and colonists were expressly prohibited from purchasing land or squatting or stealing it either. It's one thing for you to be completely ignorant of Indigenous law and history, but when it intersects with your own one would think by now you'd have at least a basic understanding.  Unless of course you're wilfully ignorant and are only interested in spreading lies and propaganda.

Comment: The Khadr payout is, above all, the ultimate object lesson in the importance of due process in our legal system and that the "court of public opinion" thankfully doesn't hold sway. If the system messes with your human rights at any point while you're in it, that's big ... big ... big. And that's regardless of whether you're guilty (I think Khadr is) or were a combatant (I think Khadr was).

But, like I said a few days ago, it's also a business decision, for a couple of reasons. 

One, I'd rather have our government pay $10 million now than $20 million ... or more ... later. Our lawyers urged us to settle because they knew the government of the day screwed up royally.

Comment: Hate to break it to you, but Canada is not and never has been a democracy.

It is a top-down English colonial system some would call a "pseudocracy", whose main goal was to muzzle settlers who were prone to thinking they had been sold a bill of goods,-- as in the rebellions of the Upper and Lower Canadas in 1837.

The word "democracy" and its cognates appears nowhere in the original Confederation Act of 1867. It appears three times in the so-called Constitution Act of 1982, twice as captions and once in graciously conferring the right to vote,-- a right shared with such egregious regimes as North Korea. The 1982 Act is a sham never ratified by Québec, cosily and paternalistically formulated by Pierre Trudeau and the remaining Premiers over the heads of Canadians.

The only threat to this canard is that Canadians will look covetously at the success of another system, and want to jettison it and the corrupt sinecurists holding them to ransom.

Hence the unease over Donald Trump.

Comment: I do applaud the Register Guard for taking this step. Over the long haul it might lead to a more relaxed and fun forum for discussion. For a long time I called for the same policy online as in the paper itself, make people use their real names, as anonymity seemed to foster bullying. But I came to understand that wouldn't allow a city employee to call out dumb behavior by government, without their getting fired.

I do have some questions going forward, regarding just what is civil and what is not. I recognize bullying when I see it, as it strives to humiliate a fellow human. But if I call someone a nincompoop for tricking my country into a war, is that civil?  How do I criticize dangerous behavior without going too far? Maybe a little more guidance as to what is considered civil would help. While civility is essential, so is honesty and clear language. Sometimes civility is just impossible. Would Michael Moore's movie,  "Where to Invade Next", be seen as civil?
Hugh Massengill, Eugene

Comment: Scott:  You mention "current" abuse.  Would you be good enough to expand on your contention.  I presume you're referencing a possible initiative which might lead to a further initiativve to control aerial spraying of herbicides.  If, indeed, that is your concern, fine, you should be addressing that particular issue, not supporting an "end run" effort which would give the Board veto power over all initiatives which Lane County voters have worked hard to, and have in fact, qualified for the ballot.  May I again state: The initiative process comes with "built-in" checks to "weed out" frivolous measures.  First, it requires a significant number of petition signatures to qualify for the ballot.  Secondly, it requires a majority of voters to support its adoption. Thirdly, it,like all ordinances, would be subject to judicial review.  At each step proponents must make a convincing argument that the measure is a) constitutional and b) desirable.  This process is called DEMOCRACY.

Comment: Of course all this assumes that had the children been kept on the reserves they would have maintained their Indian culture and grown up to be healthy well adjusted adults.  We know from recent experience that that is not so.  Since the scoop policy was abandoned over 20 years ago with a new emphasis placed on keeping  orphans within their native communities the circumstances of these children has not improved and in fact it has become arguably much worse. As of 2012 there were some 250,000 children in government care and of these fully 200,000 with native kids.  Think about it; of a group making up only 3% of the country's population it accounted for 80% of all the kids in care i.e. under guardianship or foster care.  In many cases it was single grandmothers that were raising their grandchildren in poverty and filth often surrounded by other relatives addled by drug and alcohol addictions who were as likely to abuse the children as to care for them. Indian culture maybe, desirable not.

Comment: You're confusing entry requirements with codes of conduct. There are no public universities and very few private ones that demand applicants sign an agreement stipulating to religious restrictions as a condition of acceptance.

So you might not be allowed to drink on the premises or damage school property, but none that I know of prohibits you from having sex with another consenting adult.

Comment: I think in all fairness that before the Liberals end omnibus bills for good, they should have the opportunity to try one out for their political advantage. They have a lot of ground to make up after the disastrous Harper years, and Conservative complaints are falling on my deaf ears.

It is understandable that some Liberals may be miffed, but all things considered, a responsible government should not really make a concerted effort to get rid of a policy vehicle until they road-test it.

I do hope all the parties learn a lesson from this. If you don't want omnibus bills, don't present omnibus bills. If Trudeau did not present one here, the Conservatives would have no idea how horrible they are when you are in opposition. 

Clearly I like this government, and I'm willing to pardon their many apparent inconsistencies, up to a point. They are a long way from that, so I'll heave a contented sigh amidst the wailing and moaning from past champions of omnibus bills.

Comment: Fr. Reese, I think your insights here are helpful & show your openness to understanding the the Scriptures based on a critical, studious analysis, which I'm sure your theology study has taught you to do. I find this the most insightful way to read the Scriptures - in a studious, intellectually humble manner. 

And yet I wanted to add (& you may be aware of this argument) that the word that the translation that you provided renders as "unlawful marriage" may better be translated as "adultery". I understand that the Koine Greek word "porneia" is debated, but I read an intriguing argument for its being translated as "adultery" - in the sense of secretive sexual intercourse with a man other than the woman's husband - as the more accurate term. This is based on the fact that in the Septuagint translation, the word "porneia" is often used in a phrase alongside another Greek word, "moixeia", to translate OT Hebrew phrases in which both words, in each context, refer to such manner of adultery.

Comment: I think Republicans engage in the wrong "kind" of debate on climate change.  Rather than questioning the proposed policies and regulations that politicians, bureaucrats, and even politically active scientists are pushing, they instead attack the science itself.  This is incredibly foolish.   Only scientists are qualified to understand and interpret the data.  If a clear majority of them say it's warming and humans have caused it, you're not really in a position to question that.

What you should be doing is questioning the policy that comes out of that scientific knowledge.  So the Earth is warming and man has caused it, but there are some uncertainties as to what the long-term effects are.  Last time I checked, the worst case scenario RCP8.5 projection is 1 meter of sea level rise by 2100.  That's if we do absolutely nothing, the population grows to 12 billion, coal becomes the dominant energy source for some unexplained reason, and technology does not improve in the next 100 years.

Comment: "Entry-level economics teaches us, however, that there is no relationship between cost and price."

I stopped reading at this point.  Complete nonsense.  Rubbish.  A company is entirely constrained by the cost of its product.  Imagine the company pays $3 for their widget (after all discounts and rebates are accounted for) and tries to make a profit by reselling it at $2.50.  If anyone thinks they can make a profit this way, don't go into business.  Companies survive by selling their product a prices higher than their net cost.  The difference must also pay for overhead, salaries, insurance, etc. etc.  So if the profit margin is a couple of percent before measure 97, the company must raise prices or go out of business (assuming it can't fire people to reduce cost).

I suspect that Mr. McKinney's company is not subject to the tax so of course he wants his competition to face it.

Comment: Donald Trump may be a total whack job, but that does not validate the bias in what is supposed to be journalism.  Take this quote from the editorial:

"Mr. Spicer spoke of Mr. Trump’s allegation of “wiretapping” while making air quotation marks with his hands, to imply the word had an alternative interpretation."

The unbiased reality is that "wiretapping" doesn't apply today only to people stealthily attaching a tap onto a phone wire to listen in with headphones.  The term is used colloquially to mean any clandestine interception of communication.  Pretending to be ignorant of this use of the word, and taking Mr. Trump literally in order to ridicule him is something which I had hoped to be below the standards of the Globe and Mail.  

The real story here, and I hope some journalists with integrity latch onto it, is the very specific denials issued by the politicians , such as "I have no evidence of ..."  They don't say, "I have no knowledge of...", or "I have never seen evidence of...

Comment: Parents have always had the right to opt out. However, I think young people whose bodies have reached an age of sexual maturity have rights of their own to accurate information about their reproductive systems. Comment: It really saddens me every time I read about the killing of bears because they became accustomed to eating human trash. Our Borough code officers enforces left out trash, open containers etc. He is very efficient in his work, arrives within hours, photographs the trash and tickets the offenders. If the offenders continue to offend, they are paid a visit by Fish and Wildlife officers. 
When I see trash cans left out at night I contact the folks if I can or I take photos and send them to the code officers and he comes out as soon as he gets the email.
I keep bear spray next to my door, a Orion bear deterrent "sound and brilliant flash" gun next to my door as well. When I go out for a walk, I carry my bear spray at my waist, dog spray clipped to my fluorescent vest, bear bells on my vest, walking stick and on dog leash, with two different whistles.
I live smack dab in the middle of a wild life sanctuary where bears are more common then birds.

Comment: SkeptiCat, important question, I wish I had an easy answer.  There are probably local youth workers that know much more than I.   I'd have to do a lot more intensive  research before I could really say, and each case is different. 
 But from my past experience including teaching in a county jail and counseling in a local mental health clinic, I'd guess it's often that they acquired this  self-defeating mentality from years of failure and lack of rewards for "doing the right thing."
As I've mentioned before (yes, I probably repeat myself!) our students in the jail were often smart but because of their  backgrounds had not succeeded  in school.  They earned their respect from their peers by being as "bad" as possible.  But when they passed a GED test and it was announced on the jail loudspeaker, they finally got praise for "doing good."
It's crucial to remember when we see behavior we dislike that "he is ACTING like a jerk, but that doesn't mean he IS a jerk."
